data.text: How to Choose a Bike Touring Partner

Hey everyone! I've got a quick question... how do you choose your touring partner? I'm asking because the person I'd like to go with is not that into cycling but would be willing to go, however I sense that it wouldn't be as fun for them, but I still don't want to ride alone. Any criteria you focus on? Thanks!
You don't. ......they choose you.....it shouldn't even come to a question, if it is,,,,.......you should just go solo.
data.author: Paul Rodriguez
Dan Roggi

data.text: I know it wasn't what you asked, but I must chime in to agree: give solo touring serious consideration. If you choose the wrong person, you will soon find yourself on a solo tour anyway.
data.author: Steve Johnson

data.text: that‚Äôs my main worry!
data.author: Roy Ha

data.text: I was planning my cross-county trip and intending to go solo‚Ä¶ but then a bit over a month out, a former housemate and friend asked if he could go with me. He was fit, but not a very experienced cyclist, and had very little camping experience. But he did join me for the ride, and i was happy he did! I was a good planner, navigator, and bike mechanic, but somewhat introverted; he was very outgoing and had a great sense of humor, and he broke the ice and helped us meet people in each new place we landed, in a way that I never would have. It was a fantastic trip!
data.author: Paul Lefebvre

data.text: Sounds like you fell into a great match.
data.author: Don Millikin

data.text: that's what I love about cyclists, especially tourers. They come in all forms. Some don't even know they are one until they give it a try. üëå
data.author: Mark Jensen

data.text: do some smaller rides with them , what kind of tour u planning?

data.text: the kind you‚Äôd do once a decade :D

data.text: around the world? alaska to end of south america?

data.text: around Germany. From one small town to another ‚ò∫Ô∏è Trying to see every corner of the country
data.author: Roy Ha

data.text: nice id try a overnighter or two with them first. if you come across a couple unexpected challenges on a bikepacking ride i think thatd be good to see how theyd react. then decide off that for the big tour
data.author: Christian Ramos

data.text: Thanks for your advice! much appreciated!!
data.author: Roy Ha

data.text: I recall bumping into two individuals in Alaska who had started their tour to Patagonia together. One was trying to buy a tent after they parted company on day 3. I‚Äôd rather start alone and possibly meet companions on the way than go with someone without fairly established compatibility.
data.author: John Knapp

data.text: these were just two platonic people attempting to share a tent? I can barely stand myself in a tent (ugh, self, you smell and you cluttered the tent with all your junk), let alone a second person that isn't my SO.
data.author: Braden Graham

data.text: agreed, I don't think I'd even share a tent with my spouse... On day 11 of my first big tour, and I stink. At least it's only my stink.
data.author: Dee Jacobs

data.text: My SO and I don't even share tents! Her stank is hers, and mine is mine.
data.author: John McGee

data.text: My rule of thumb is don't tour with anyone who hasn't at least done a multi-day tour before. Just not worth the hassle. And before you even plan to tour with someone, make sure you're on the same page about how you chose to tour. Are they going to want to stay in a hotel every night? Eat out for every meal? How many miles are they comfortable doing each day? What is their bike capable of? If it rains for three days straight, would they be okay biking in the rain or would they prefer taking those days off? There isn't a "right" answer for any of these questions but you need to at least have similar answers in order for the tour to be enjoyable to BOTH of you.
data.author: Ben Grad

data.text: I get it! It makes sense. I was also interested in knowing what questions other people ask or what things they look too! Thanks Ben. :)
data.author: Roy Ha

data.text: I went once with someone I barely knew and introduced her to bike touring. Started in AlaskaüòÇ. Multi month tour and we‚Äôre still friends. Went once with someone I thought I knew via FB and we didn‚Äôt last two weeks together and are no longer friends. Try to ask basic questions on styles, but there are no guarantees. Good luck!
data.author: Kim Johnson

data.text: If that person is willing to go well that is all that is needed to try, take ot easy a short trip through nice places where you can experience the advantages of cycle touring, wild camp, a rail trail etc, i ve found it easier to ride with people that dont know nothing at all but willing to try rather than experienced travellers with whom you might have already very different ways of travelling (stops, routes etc)
data.author: Tomas Aperlo

data.text: I get the logic. It makes sense. They‚Äôre not yet used to a specific way of touring and would be interested to build on that!
data.author: Roy Ha

data.text: Just go on your own! Go at your own pace. Stop when you want. Eat when you want. No waiting around. Nobody to blame if it turns to üí© other than yourself. There‚Äôs lots of advantages to a solo trip!
data.author: Michael Christopher Burkey

data.text: Solo is THE way to go!
data.author: Joyce Riecker

data.text: I‚Äôm a big fan of solo touring. 40,000 km more or less later I have had many wonderful shared experiences ranging from a few minutes to a few weeks with other cyclists
data.author: Alison Wheeler

data.text: do not take a partner that only kinda wants to go because you gotta love bicycle riding ALL day for days on end or else it is no fun for someone just 'willing' to go. post your ride on Crazy Guy On A Bike under companions, there are lots of folks who would probably love to go ;<)
data.author: Fred Dixon

data.text: I think we'll survive!
data.author: Matthew James

data.text: Depends on the situation - my partner and I met just before he was suppose to go on a world tour. I didn‚Äôt even own a bike let alone know if I‚Äôd enjoy it ‚Äî but I went on the road with him and now we‚Äôve been cycle touring long term now for 4 years & I couldn‚Äôt live without it! One of the best adventures of my life üòÑ definitely set out some parameters about how you want to cycle together, but flexibility and working together once you‚Äôre out there is key! Ultimately it‚Äôs super fun sharing the adventures with someone
data.author: Becky Norman

data.text: Is it a bicycle expedition or a holiday of cycling. I cycled withy husband who would never normally cycle. If you consider route and change expectations it could be a great holiday, maybe not something to brag about with the how far you rode, but I prefer to have a great cycling holiday.
data.author: Shirley Anne

data.text: it‚Äôs a holiday kinda tour ‚ò∫Ô∏è
data.author: Roy Ha

data.text: I turned my brother onto touring. 6 day tour last year; two week tour starting next week‚Ä¶.cross country next year
data.author: Ed Chimahusky

data.text: Do not hide anything. Be very honest about yourself and your idiosyncrasies. Make them do the same. It is not the big things that will bother you, it is the little things they did not tell you. You have lots of advice in the other posts. It is so hard to know about a person until you face some challenges. Bicycle travel will provide plenty of them. My wife and I did our first tour as a 3 month trip across the US. I was very experienced, a professional bike mechanic, a long-distance hiker, and bike tourer. She had ridden RGBRAI and one other supported tour. We are still together after cycling around the world, an 18-month tour of Europe, the Middle East, and Central America, a 3-month tour of Mexico, and several long rides in the US. I share this because we talked to each other about everything before we agreed to undertake the first tour. I mean everything. "Do you get up in the night to relieve yourself? Do you Snore? Do you want motels every now and then? Do you like to talk to strangers? How often will you stop to take pictures? How fast do you ride? Are you goal focused? Hope you get the idea.
data.author: Bill Heimann

data.text: perfectly! Thanks for the detailed answer! Especially the questions ‚ò∫Ô∏è
data.author: Roy Ha

data.text: One word‚Äîsolo
data.author: Mike Samsen

data.text: Try the person on a short credit card tour first.
data.author: Jack Kessler

data.text: well.. that is a tough one. I went on a bike touring trip with a friend, I first met him, he mentioned that he wanted to do a cross america tour, and I thought it was a fantastic goal. then over time, I noticed that he actually did it. He did the East Coast route, then he attempted to do Trans-Am route, then he put that on hold. and he decided to do the pacific coast. (I already loved cycling with a passion but hard to find anyone who are equally passionate.) I chatted with him, and decided to join him. We met up, and we went on a cycling tour. it went smoothly, of course there were some bumps along the way, but things worked out well. My advice, first check to see if you and the partner is compatible, for example, go on a camping trip (short one) and see how things go, any issues, any tensions, any " button pushing", any complaints. then if everything go well, then you go on next step, go on a bike trip (short one) and see how things go. if everything is good, then you and your partner can meet together to discuss the logistics and the supplies and so on. then go on that trip. also, make sure communicate with your partner, ie: any tiredness, any illness, injuries, whatnot, then work out a solution that works well. and everyone is happy about. then things will go well. (sorry for the long post)
data.author: Paul Kvarnberg

data.text: the long post is helpful and lovely. Thank you!!
data.author: Roy Ha

data.text: Start with one night or two night tours. They may get the bug. If they don't you will know, but a two nighter can be endured by anyone. There are also FB groups for people looking for touring partners. https://www.facebook.com/groups/1660651324204126/ and https://www.facebook.com/groups/309085539288044/
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: I ride alone, you will meet folks along the way.
data.author: Jean Phillips

data.text: None of my friends are avid cyclists, so unless I meet someone I like on the road, it's just me on me Pat Malone!
data.author: Mark Jensen

data.text: We are always 3. Counting me, myself, and I. That way I only have one a**hole to deal with.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: I met someone wile on tour, the guy did not even own a bike in a matter of a couple days he had a bike, panniers and kit. We had the most amazing time. When we finished, he went on touring for a 1500km solo. Today we are very good buddies.

data.text: that‚Äôs amazing! Seriously

data.author: Sean Quinn

data.text: Only travel solo. Much easier.
data.author: Lee Hollenbeck

data.text: If you have a choice, you are extremely lucky. I have travelled with my best bud, how is not as into cycling as I am. After a few days he gets bored. Now I plan only to travel solo, that way I have nobody to please, but me.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: Unless I'm riding really remote spaces, I always meet riders... It's often more company than I want. ;-). Coordinating a ride with a companion is a whole different ride...... Especially if they're novice riders.
data.author: Samuel Lea

data.text: I rode the entire East coast with a very good friend of over 30 years. We made some rules, knowing there could be problems along the way. We both needed to be in the same page. 1st we both knew our cycling abilities were almost the same. We agreed on average mileage we would like to accomplish each day knowing it could be more or less. We always stayed together. We agreed on sleeping arrangements. We did Hotels and motels. Food was never an issue. We pretty much Eat the same things. At the end of each day we always had a celebratory microbrewed beer. Discuss everything you possibly could keeping an open mind before it becomes an issue.
data.author: Ronald Harlos

data.text: thank you Ronald for your story ‚ò∫Ô∏è
data.author: Roy Ha

data.text: we the celebratory microbrew also
data.author: Ed Chimahusky

data.text: My wife and I have twice been on the road together for over year's time. We have very few rules. One is, if we get separated go back to the last place we were stopped together and wait there until the other person shows up. We do not go looking for the other person, too easy to just miss them somewhere.
data.author: Bill Heimann

data.text: I would go with anyone who is willing to put up with me.
data.author: James Schoettgen

data.text: I'm engaged to him üôÇ
